name: Vincent Rago
comment info: The map compares the populations of white people and people of color from the 2010 and 2020 censuses. Each arrow shows the percentage change for county census tracts with a change of more than 1 percent. Census tracts are geographic regions that are designated by the Census Bureau and have, on average, about 4,000 people, though they can range in size from 1,200 to 8,000 people. Note that for this map, white is defined as non-Hispanic white.

name: Anna
comment info:
I notice that overall from 2010 to 2020 the share of people of color has increased significantly, with the growth experienced overtaking that of the white population by manyfold.  In particular, there has been a lot of growth in the POC population in the midwest and the east. The blue arrows are most concentrated around large cities on the map. Additionally, counties with longer arrows, or more growth, are concentrated around cities also. While growth in POC can be seen across the entire map, that of the white population is limited to a few areas. Mainly, the share of the white population in the southeast. 

To start, I wonder what is prompting the substantial growth in the POC population. Besides the concentration of this growth around large cities, I am intrigued by how evenly this growth is distributed in other parts of the map in the Midwest and the east coast. On the other hand, I wonder why there is far less growth in the western part of the United, especially California which I believe has one of the highest if not the highest minority populations in the U.S.

This relates to me and my community as an Asian American living in a white-dominated area. It is nice to visually see the significant increase in the POC population and process that the areas we live in are becoming more diverse. As the POC population increases, hopefully, that will parallel their representation and inclusion.

A Political Presence in Population Rates-

Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

This map compares the white and people of color populations from the 2010 and the 2020 U.S. Census.  Each arrow shows the percentage change by county with a change of more than 1 percent.  Note that for this map white is defined as non-Hispanic white. 

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?"  and “How will this affect you and your community?”  Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in this graph. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included this map and much more.  

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs).
View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 
graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex).
